Why the CIO Canâ€™t Lead Your AI Strategy â€” And Why You Now Need a CAIO
AI is not an IT upgrade.
Itâ€™s not â€œsomething the CIO can handle aloneâ€.
Itâ€™s a fundamental shift in how businesses operate and it demands leadership far beyond systems and servers.
This is where the Chief AI Officer (CAIO) comes in.
 Not as a luxury,  but as an essential leadership function for any organisation serious about getting value from AI.
Whatâ€™s the issue?
CIOs are under pressure to â€œownâ€ AI because it sits on top of infrastructure. 
But AI transformation isnâ€™t about infrastructure. Itâ€™s about change management, culture, and capability.
The result?
The majority AI projects are stalling at pilot stage.
Teams adopt tools in silos with no support.
Organisations end up with shadow AI, unclear ROI, and rising risk.
And the real problem?
No one is leading the behavioural change required to make AI stick.
Why a CAIO is now business-critical
A good CAIO is not an engineer-in-chief. Theyâ€™re a translator between business value and AI opportunity - someone who can redesign workflows, build internal capability, and lead cultural adoption.
Hereâ€™s what they focus on:
  Change Management
 AI isnâ€™t about plugging in tools. Itâ€™s about rethinking how work gets done and who does it. That requires clear delivery rhythms, process retirement plans, and visible wins.
  Cultural Adoption
 Fear slows everything down. A CAIO works across teams to normalise AI use, provide reassurance, and create safe spaces to test, fail, and learn.
  Training & Enablement
 Most staff havenâ€™t been trained. Many are using AI without guardrails. A CAIO puts proper education in place from awareness to hands-on skill-building.
This isnâ€™t about one role replacing another. Itâ€™s about right seat, right remit.
Still not sure? Here's what weâ€™re seeing in real businesses:
1 in 4 SMEs in the UK & Ireland have GenAI live.
75% of knowledge workers are using AIâ€¦ but only 1% of firms say theyâ€™re mature.
Over 50% of employees have had no formal training and are improvising their way through it.
That gap? Thatâ€™s your CAIOâ€™s job to close.
What the CAIO should deliver in the first 100 days:
Phase 1: Diagnose
 Map top 10 workflows, identify data gaps, define outcome metrics.
Phase 2: Design
 Select 2â€“3 pilots with real commercial upside. Lock in training and comms.
Phase 3: Deliver
 Launch MVPs. Track time saved, accuracy gained, or revenue unlocked.
Phase 4: Decide
 Scale what works, shut down what doesnâ€™t. No vanity projects.
AI wonâ€™t deliver returns just because you bought a licence. It delivers when you change how people work.
Thatâ€™s not the CIOâ€™s job. It never was.
If youâ€™re a business leader, and you want AI to scale with purpose, with safety, and with results itâ€™s time to bring a CAIO to the table in the UK.

The new CTO Playbook: From systems architect to value architect
I think we can all agree that the role of the CTO has changed, especially in light of what has been happening the the world of AI over the past few years.
Youâ€™re no longer here to run the tech stack. Youâ€™re here to move the value needle.
Itâ€™s not about uptime. Itâ€™s about upside.
Itâ€™s not about scale. Itâ€™s about impact at scale.
Itâ€™s not about tech strategy. Itâ€™s about business strategy, enabled by tech.
If youâ€™re not already playing by these new rules, I would argue that you are holding the title - but not the seat.
My take on the new playbook?
[1] Obsess Over Outcomes, Not Output
Shipping features is easy. Moving metrics is hard.
 - The modern CTO doesnâ€™t focus about how many stories got closed this sprint
 - They focus on what changed for the business - and how tech made that possible
 - They ask: Did we move revenue? Reduce churn? Open a new market?
[2] Drive Commercial Impact, Not Just Code Quality
Clean code that doesnâ€™t drive value is just elegant waste.
 - The best engineers think in loops and syntax. The best CTOs think in leverage.
 - Every tech decision should have a commercial consequence.
 - If your engineering team doesnâ€™t understand how the company makes money, thatâ€™s on you.
[3] See AI as a Business Tool, Not Just an Engineering Trick
LLMs arenâ€™t toys. Theyâ€™re leverage.
 - Process automation, enhanced decision-making, customer experience - this is where AI earns its keep.
 - The CTOâ€™s job is to connect AI to ROI, not just run proof-of-concepts that can gather dust.
[4] Design Business Models, Not Just Systems
This is the \""final boss\"" level.
 - The real differentiators wonâ€™t be in your backend - theyâ€™ll be in your business model.
 - Usage-based pricing, data monetisation, embedded finance - this is your domain now.
 - Your job is no longer to keep the lights on. Itâ€™s to invent new rooms.
We used to say the CTO was the most technical person in the room. Not anymore.
Now youâ€™re expected to be a translator, a strategist, and a growth enabler.
You donâ€™t need to know every line of code - but youâ€™d better understand every lever of value.
CTOs who obsess over architecture are at risk of being replaced by those who obsess over value.
If your conversations are still about:
 - Systems instead of outcomes
 - Platforms instead of profit
 - Features instead of flow
Then it's time to lean into the new playbook.

Bang! I've been shot!
Walking through sun-drenched Shoreditch this morning, I was preparing in my mind for my next meeting when suddenly I was struck.
Not by a bullet (fortunately) but by the spray from a water pistol.
I spun round to see my young assailants gleaming with delight and preparing for a \""sharp exit\"".
But my immediate reaction was not anger (and this surprised me) but instead a burst out laughing and congratulating them on \""getting me\"".
I couldn't get the smile off my face.
With our screen filled with dire warnings for youth in the UK, it was reassuring to see that \""boys would be boys\"" enjoying a childish prank.
And for me, this was yet again another reminder not to take the world too seriously. To take every moment to experience joy.
Our business world, especially that of the entrepreneur, can be a stressful environment, so let's not forget that we chose this path to spend our precious minutes on this earth doing what we love. If you are not finding joy in what you are doing, it might be worth considering a change.
Now, where can I buy a water pistol to get my own back :)

Weâ€™re facing an Organizational Paralysis Crisis no one is talking about. 
For nearly half a century, companies thrived in stable macroeconomic environments. 
This stability made it easy to justify decisions like centralizing operations, building centers of excellence, and outsourcing, all in service of optimizing the bottom line. But these optimizations have created a fundamental weakness in our organizational structures that's becoming painfully apparent today. 
Think of an organization as a living being. To function effectively, it needs three integrated systems: neural pathways to detect and transmit information, a brain to make decisions, and muscles to execute coordinated action. 
The problem? Organizations today are being bombarded with unprecedented stimuli: tariffs, geopolitical tensions, AI disruption, increasing uncertainty and accelerating technological change. 
However, our obsession with efficiency has dulled our organizational senses. Democratized decision-making has created multiple competing brains, and our muscles are now receiving conflicting signals, leading to paralysis when decisive action is needed most.
The most alarming reality I'm witnessing is threefold:
  Many companies can't sense changes... ostrichification of organizations if you will
  Those that do struggle with fragmented decision-making.
  Even with clear decisions, execution is hindered by fragmented structures each playing to conflicting and self serving purposes
The disruption is already here. The organizations that survive won't be those with the most efficient processes, but those with the most responsive nervous systems.
In the coming weeks, I'll explore how AI is exposing organizational weaknesses and the radical changes needed to thrive. Stay tuned for insights on the new organizational model emerging from this chaos.

ğ“ğ¡ğğ¦: We want Agents EVERYWHERE to automate ALL THE THINGS.
ğŒğ: Great, which things?
ğ“ğ¡ğğ¦: We donâ€™t know, thatâ€™s why youâ€™re here.
ğŒğ: Cool. Agentic AI doesnâ€™t start with technology, it starts with understanding the business. That means breaking down real-world processes into clear tasks that can be automated, orchestrated, and governed by Agents.
ğ“ğ¡ğğ¦: Pfft, shut up Stuart, that sounds like boring grunt work, weâ€™ve seen the demos, just give us Agents.
I said this three months ago:
â€œWe have to start with the business, and more specifically for Agents, the processes of the business. The boring moral of the story is start with the business, understand your processes, and get your data in order. These are the hard parts, the grunt work, the reality on the ground, that nobody seems to want to talk about. But if you do it, when the technology is ready, you will be first out of the gate to utilise it, and outpace your market.â€
I love being vindicated and Pradeep Sanyal just posted a new Capgemini report and guess what? Yep. Start with business and processes.
This is NOT the traditional top-down model onto the business as weâ€™re used to with traditional IT practices, you start from actual business activities, creating digital definitions of how those processes are done, mapping these to Agents with highly-defined goals, roles, and boundaries.
You could start like his:
- Mapping real operational processes
- Identifying automation candidates
- Designing Agent workflows
- Optimising data and guardrails
- Then deploy and scale Agents.
- All done in tandem with multidisciplinary humans
Thereâ€™s lots in this report around structured processes, importance of good data, clear guardrails, strong governance, human-AI collaboration by design, and they were honest enough to note Agentic systems are not trivial as they introduce distributed decision-making, emergent behavior, and unpredictability that traditional IT systems donâ€™t.
Much of the stuff Iâ€™ve been talking about, so I wonâ€™t rehash it all here, you get the point.
If we start with technology, we get more technology, if we start with the business and customers, we get moreâ€¦
Iâ€™ll leave you with a quote from the document:
â€œLeaping into agentic AI immediately without first evaluating simpler automation options is akin to creating a solution in search of a problemâ€.
Amen. Happy Friday.
